text: Hello everyone. Welcome back to the
Daily English Loop. This is the place
where learning English becomes part of
your everyday rhythm. Easy, fun, and
natural. I'm Alex.
>> And I'm Lisa. Hello, Alex. It is so good
to be here with you today. And a huge
hello to all our wonderful listeners
tuning in from all over the world. Alex,
how are you doing today? You look very
comfortable and happy.
I am doing fantastic, Lisa. Thank you. I
have my large cup of coffee right here,
so I am fully awake and feeling great. I
always need my morning coffee to get
started. How about you? You are glowing
with energy today.
>> Oh, thank you, Alex. I feel really good.
I actually just finished a yoga session
before coming to the studio, so I feel
very fresh and full of energy.
>> Yoga? Wow, that is impressive. I usually
just sit in my chair and stretch my
arms. That's my version of yoga.
>> Hey, stretching is good too. Any
movement is better than no movement.
>> That is very true. And actually, because
we are both feeling so good today, I
think it is the perfect day to talk
about a very important topic. Today we
are going to talk about health. Health.
That is such an essential topic. It's
something we all think about or at least
something we should think about every
day.
>> Exactly. Without health, we have
nothing. So today, we will explore
different parts of a healthy life. But
before we dive in, I have a small favor
to ask our listeners. If you enjoy our
conversations, please subscribe to the
Daily English Loop.
>> Yes, please do. And don't forget to hit
that like button. It really helps our
channel grow and helps other English
learners find us. Sharing is caring, so
share this episode with your friends and
family, too.
>> Ideally, share it with someone you want
to be healthy with. Okay, Lisa, are you
ready to start?
>> I am so ready, Alex. Health is a big
word. Where should we begin? Let's start
with the part nobody likes but everybody
needs. Let's start with going to the
doctor.
>> The doctor. H. Yes. When we feel sick,
we have to go to the doctor or sometimes
to a big hospital if it is serious.
>> Right. A hospital is that big place with
many doctors and nurses. But usually for
small things, we just go to a clinic or
see our family doctor. Tell me, Lisa, do
you like going to the doctor?
>> That is a tricky question. I don't think
anyone loves it. I don't wake up and
say, "Yay, I want to go to the doctor
today." But I go when I need to. I know
the doctor is there to help me. What
about you, Alex? Are you a brave
patient?
>> To be honest, Lisa, I am a bit of a
baby. I don't like needles and I don't
like the smell of the doctor's office.
But like you said, I go when I feel
sick. For example, last winter I had a
terrible cold.
>> Gh. A cold. That is the most common
sickness. What happened? Did you have a
runny nose?
>> Oh, yes. I had a runny nose, a sore
throat, and I felt so tired. My energy
was zero. I just wanted to stay in bed
and sleep for a week.
>> That sounds miserable. So, did you go to
the doctor immediately?
>> Not immediately. I waited 2 days
thinking I would get better, but I
didn't. So, I finally went. I walked in
and said, "Hello, doctor. I think I have
a bad cold."
>> And was the doctor helpful? Usually,
they are very kind.
>> Yes, he was very nice. He asked me the
standard question, "Alex, how do you
feel?"
>> How do you feel? That is the most
important question. Listeners, remember
that phrase. You can answer, "I feel
sick." Or, "I feel weak."
>> Exactly. Or you can be specific about
your body parts. I told him, "My head
hurts."
>> My head hurts. A headache. That is the
worst. It makes it hard to think.
>> It really does. Or sometimes people say,
"My stomach hurts."
>> Oh, a stomach ache. That is very
uncomfortable. Usually that happens when
we eat something bad,
>> right? But in my case, it was just a
cold. The doctor checked my temperature.
He said I had a small fever.
>> A fever is when your body gets too hot,
right?
>> Yes, he checked my ears. He looked into
my throat and he listened to my
breathing. He was very professional.
>> And did he give you any medicine?
>> He did. He gave me some medicine to help
with the headache, but mostly he gave me
advice. Let me guess. Did he tell you to
drink water?
>> You guessed it. He said, "Alex, go home,
drink a lot of water, and sleep."
>> Water and sleep. It sounds so simple,
but it really is the best medicine for a
cold. Our bodies fix themselves when we
sleep.
>> It is true. I followed his advice. I
drank gallons of water and I slept for
12 hours. And in 2 days, I felt like a
new man. I was back to my happy self.
>> That is a great story, Alex. It shows
that we shouldn't be afraid of the
doctor. They know what is best.
>> Definitely. Now, Lisa, what about you?
Do you have any doctor stories?
>> Well, not a medical doctor, but last
month I went to the dentist.
>> Ah, the dentist. The doctor for our
teeth. That is a scary one for many
people.
>> It can be scary because of the noise.
But I actually like going to the
dentist. I go every 6 months for a
checkup.
>> Every 6 months? Wow. You are very
disciplined. Why is it important to go
so often?
>> It is important because I want a healthy
smile. A checkup is just a routine
visit. The dentist looks at my teeth to
make sure there are no problems.
>> I see. So, you don't wait until your
tooth hurts.
>> Exactly. If you wait until it hurts, it
might be a big problem. I prefer to go
when everything is fine.
>> That is very smart. So, what happened at
your visit? The dentist was a lovely
woman. She said the famous words,
"Hello, Lisa. Please open your mouth."
>> "Open wide. I always feel silly sitting
there with my mouth open."
>> "Me, too." But she looked at my teeth.
She checked my gums. And then she
smiled. She said, "Lisa, your teeth look
perfect. Good job."
>> That is the best feeling. It's like
getting an A+ on a test at school.
>> It really is. I felt very proud. She
told me to keep doing what I'm doing.
>> And what is her advice for healthy
teeth?
>> Very simple. Brush your teeth in the
morning and at night and don't eat too
much sugar.
>> Ah, sugar. That is the enemy of teeth.
>> It is. So going to the doctor or the
dentist is a good thing. It helps us
stay broken. Oh wait, no. It helps us
stay fixed and healthy,
>> right? It keeps us running smoothly like
a car. Okay. So, that is the medical
side of things, but we don't want to
just go to the doctor. We want to stay
healthy every day, so we don't need the
doctor.
>> Exactly. Prevention is better than cure.
So, let's talk about my favorite topic,
exercise.
>> Exercise, moving our bodies. I know you
love this, Lisa. You mentioned yoga
earlier. Do you also go to a gym?
>> I do. I joined a gym last year. I try to
go three or four times a week.
>> Three or four times? That is dedication.
What do you do there?
>> Well, first I warm up. Then I like to
use the treadmill.
>> The treadmill? That is the machine where
you run, but you don't go anywhere.
>> Yes, that's the one. It sounds funny
when you say it like that, but I like it
because I can watch TV or listen to
music while I walk or run.
>> Do you run fast?
>> I mostly walk very fast. It's called
power walking. It gets my heart beating
fast. It's very good for your heart
health.
>> And do you lift heavy things?
>> Sometimes I lift small weights. I'm not
trying to be a bodybuilder, Alex. I just
want to be strong.
>> Small weights are good. They make your
arms and back strong. That helps with
everyday life, like carrying groceries.
>> Exactly. And how about you, Alex? You
said you stretch in your chair, but do
you do any real exercise? Hey, chair
stretching is hard work. Just kidding. I
actually don't like the gym. I prefer to
be outside.
>> Outdoors? That is wonderful. Fresh air
is so good for you. What do you do
outside?
>> I like to go to the park near my house.
It has a nice path with many trees. I
usually go for a slow jog in the
morning.
>> A jog? That is like a slow run, right?
>> Yes. I am not fast. I am like a turtle,
but I am moving. I love seeing the birds
and feeling the morning sun.
>> That sounds beautiful. Morning exercise
is a great way to start the day. It
wakes up your brain.
>> It does. But honestly, Lisa, sometimes
it's hard to start. The bed is so warm
and the outside is cold. Do you ever
feel lazy?
>> Oh, absolutely. Everyone feels lazy
sometimes. There are days when I just
want to sit on the sofa and watch
movies.
>> So, how do you motivate yourself? I
think about how I feel after the
exercise. You know that feeling?
>> Yes. The good tired.
>> Exactly. My body feels tired, but my
mind feels happy and clear. I feel proud
of myself. That feeling motivates me.
>> That is great advice. Focus on the
feeling after, not the pain during.
Also, I listen to music. Music helps a
lot.
>> Oh, definitely. Upbeat music makes you
want to move. A good playlist is
essential.
>> And water. We mentioned water for
sickness, but water for exercise is even
more important.
>> Yes, I always carry a water bottle with
me at the gym. When we sweat, we lose
water. We have to put it back in.
>> Hydration is key. So, listeners, you
don't need to run a marathon. Just walk,
dance, or play in the park. Just move
your body.
>> Yes. Find something you enjoy. If you
like it, you will do it.
>> Okay. So, we have visited the doctor and
we have exercised at the gym and the
park. Now, I'm getting hungry.
>> Me, too. All this talk about running
makes me want to eat.
>> Let's talk about the third pillar of
health. Food.
>> Food. This is the most delicious topic.
What we put inside our bodies is the
fuel for our lives.
>> You are so right. If you put bad fuel in
a car, it breaks. It's the same for us.
So, Alex's question of the day. What is
your favorite healthy food? Lisa
>> H, that is hard because I love food, but
I think I have to say fruit. I have a
sweet tooth and fruit is like nature's
candy.
>> Nature's candy. I like that description.
What is your number one fruit?
>> I love apples. Specifically, red apples.
I love the sound they make when you bite
them.
>> Crunchy.
>> Yes. so crunchy and juicy. And they say
an apple a day keeps the doctor away.
>> That is a very famous English idiom and
it's mostly true. Apples have vitamins
and fiber.
>> What about you, Alex? Are you a fruit
lover?
>> I am. My favorite is the banana.
>> The banana, a classic choice.
>> It is the perfect snack. It comes in its
own wrapper. I eat a banana every
morning with my breakfast. It gives me
instant energy.
>> That is great. Bananas are full of
potassium, very good for your muscles.
>> But we can't just live on fruit. We need
vegetables, too.
>> Vegetables, the colorful part of the
meal. Do you like vegetables?
>> I do, actually. I love carrots. They're
crunchy, like apples.
>> Carrots are great for your eyes. My mom
always told me that.
>> And I try to eat a big salad for lunch.
>> A salad is a fantastic lunch option.
It's light so you don't feel sleepy in
the afternoon. What do you put in your
salad?
>> I keep it simple. Lettuce, cucumbers,
tomatoes, and maybe some olive oil.
>> Sounds fresh and delicious. I love
broccoli. You know, the ones that look
like little green trees.
>> The little trees. Yes. Some children
hate them, but I think they're tasty if
you cook them right.
>> Me, too. I steamed them and put a little
lemon juice on top. Yum.
>> Okay, so fruit and vegetables are
essential, but what about the main
meals? Breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
>> They say breakfast is the most important
meal of the day.
>> I agree. If I skip breakfast, I get
grumpy.
>> Me, too. I get hangry. Hungry and angry.
>> Hangry. That's a great word. So, what is
a typical breakfast for you, Lisa?
>> I usually have yogurt with some fruit
and granola. It's quick and healthy.
>> That sounds nice. I usually cook eggs. I
like boiled eggs or scrambled eggs. They
have protein which keeps me full for a
long time.
>> Eggs are a superfood. And for dinner?
>> For dinner I try to eat something warm.
Maybe grilled chicken or some fish.
>> Fish is excellent. It's very good for
your brain. I try to eat fish twice a
week
>> and rice or potatoes on the side.
>> Yes, but not too much. It's all about
balance.
>> Balance. That's the magic word. Because
let's be honest, Lisa, we are not
perfect. Do you ever eat unhealthy food?
>> Of course. I'm human. I love chocolate.
>> Chocolate is my weakness, too. And
pizza. On Friday nights, I love to order
a big pepperoni pizza.
>> And that's okay.
>> It is.
>> Yes. As long as it's not every day. If
you eat healthy food like salads, fruit,
and fish on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday,
Thursday, then on Friday you can have a
treat.
>> That makes me feel better. A treat is a
reward.
>> Exactly. If you try to be perfect 100%
of the time, you will be unhappy. And
being happy is also part of being
healthy.
>> That is such a beautiful point, Lisa.
Mental health and happiness are just as
important as eating broccoli.
>> Yes, stress is bad for your body. So,
relax, eat a cookie sometimes, and
smile.
>> I love that philosophy. So, let's do a
quick review for our listeners. We
covered a lot today.
>> We did. First, the doctor. Don't be
afraid. Go for checkups.
>> And if you have a cold, drink water and
sleep.
>> Second, exercise. You don't need a fancy
gym. You can walk, run in the park, or
do yoga. Just find something you love.
>> And remember the good tired feeling.
That is your goal.
>> Third, food. Eat a rainbow. red apples,
orange carrots, green broccoli,
>> and don't forget protein like eggs and
fish. But also, don't feel guilty about
a small piece of cake on your birthday
>> or a pizza on Friday.
>> Exactly. It really isn't difficult when
you break it down. Small changes can
make a big difference.
>> You don't have to change your whole life
in one day. Start with drinking one
extra glass of water or walking for 10
minutes. Step by step. That is how you
learn English and that is how you get
healthy.
>> Well, Alex, I feel healthier just
talking about this.
>> Me too. I think I am going to go for a
walk after we finish recording.
>> And I am going to eat an apple.
>> Perfect. Well, our time is almost up for
today's episode. This was a lot of fun,
Lisa.
>> It was wonderful. I hope our listeners
learned some useful new words and maybe
felt inspired to take care of
themselves. I am sure they did. To
everyone listening, thank you so much
for spending your time with us on the
Daily English Loop.
>> We love having you here. Don't forget to
subscribe so you don't miss our next
topic. We have some great ones coming
up.
>> And please leave us a comment below. We
have a question for you.
>> Yes, tell us what is one healthy thing
you like to do. Do you like to swim? Do
you love strawberries? Do you meditate?
or tell us your favorite unhealthy
treat. We want to know that, too.
>> We read all your comments and they make
our day.
>> They really do. All right, everyone.
Stay happy, stay healthy, and keep
practicing your English.
>> Goodbye for now. See you next time.
>> Bye, everyone. Take care.
